prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. If $f(x)$ is a polynomial of degree 7, and $g(x)$ is a polynomial of degree 7, then what is the product of the minimum and the maximum possible degrees of $f(x) + g(x)$?
gpt_response:
To find the product of the minimum and maximum possible degrees of $f(x) + g(x)$, we need to consider the possible scenarios that could arise when adding two polynomials of degree 7.

Given that $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are both polynomials of degree 7, the highest degree term of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is $ax^7$ and $bx^7$ respectively, where $a$ and $b$ are non-zero constants. When we add the two polynomials, the highest degree term of the resulting polynomial $f(x) + g(x)$ will be $ax^7 + bx^7 = (a+b)x^7$. 

Thus, the resulting polynomial $f(x) + g(x)$ will have a maximum possible degree of 7 when the coefficients of the highest degree terms in $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ are non-zero and have the same sign.

On the other hand, the resulting polynomial $f(x) + g(x)$ will have a minimum possible degree of 0 when the coefficients of the highest degree terms in $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ cancel out, i.e., when $a = -b$. In this case, the highest degree term of the resulting polynomial will be zero.

Therefore, the product of the minimum and maximum possible degrees of $f(x) + g(x)$ is $0 \times 7 = 0$.
solution_prompt:

On the other hand, the resulting polynomial $f(x) + g(x)$ will have a minimum possible degree of 0 when the coefficients of the highest degree terms in $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ cancel out, i.e., when $a = -b$. In this case, the highest degree term of the resulting polynomial will be zero.

Therefore, the product of the minimum and maximum possible degrees of $f(x) + g(x)$ is $0 \times 7 = 0$.
